data.title: When I use a word . . . . Medical anniversaries in 2023
data.meta_description: My list of 66 medically related anniversaries for 2023 (events in years ending ’23 and’73) includes:● foundation of the Chelsea Physic Garden (1673);● foundation of The Lancet by Thomas Wakley (October 1823);● Roe v Wade (1973);● Twenty five births include: Hans Berger, German neurologist; Aimé Bonpland, French physician and botanist; Alexis Carrel, French surgeon and Nobel prize winner; Lloyd Conover, American pharmaceutical chemist; Félix d'Herelle, French-Canadian microbiologist; Théodore de Mayerne, Swiss physician; Carl Djerassi, American pharmaceutical chemist and novelist; Sigismund Elsholtz, German physician, botanist, and alchemist; Daniel Gajdusek, American virologist; Beatrix Hamburg, American psychiatrist; Richard Mead, English physician; Arthur Jensen, American educational psychologist; Otto Loewi, German pharmacologist; Georg Balthasar Metzger, German physician and scientist; William P Murphy Jr, American physician and inventor of medical devices; William Petty, English physician and political economist; Arnold S Relman, American physician and editor; Caspar Schamberger, German surgeon; Giovanni Antonio Scopoli, Italian physician and scientist; Ludwik Teichmann, Polish physician and anatomist; Alfred Russell Wallace, English naturalist; and Thomas Young, English scientist and polymath;● Thirteen deaths include: Francis Anthony, English apothecary, physician, and alchemist; Matthew Baillie, Scottish physician and pathologist; John Caius, English physician; Regnier De Graaf, Dutch physician, physiologist, and anatomist; Walter Rudolf Hess, Swiss physiologist; Edward Jenner, English physician; Dickinson W Richards, American physician; Wilhelm Röntgen, German physicist; Antony van Leeuwenhoek, Dutch microscopist; Justus von Liebig, German chemist; and Selman Waksman, Ukrainian-American biochemist;● Eleven biomedical texts published, written by Avicenna, Persian physician, astronomer, and philosopher; Gaspard Bauhin, Swiss botanist; William Budd, English physician; Aleixeu de Abreu, Portuguese physician and tropical pathologist; John Lelamour, English schoolmaster; Lucretius, Roman poet and philosopher; Marcello Malpighi, Italian physician; Girolamo Mercuriale, Italian physician; Raymond Pearl, American biologist; Costanzo Varolio, Italian anatomist and physician; Charles White, English physician; and Wilhelm Wundt, German physiologist;● compilation of the Lelamour Herbal by John Lelamour, English schoolmaster (1373);● anatomical, biochemical, haematological, microbiological, and physiological observations by Gasparus Aselli, Italian physician; Gerhard Henrik Armauer Hansen, Norwegian physician; William Prout, English chemist, physician, and theologian; Gaston Ramon, French biologist; Hilaire-Marin Rouelle, French chemist; and Antony van Leeuwenhoek, Dutch microscopist;● Foundation of the pharmaceutical companies Novo Nordisk in Denmark (1923) and Sanofi in France (1973);● Nobel prizes awarded to Banting and Macleod (1923) and to von Frisch, Lorenz, and Tinbergen (1973).
data.text:
Medical anniversaries in 2023

For the past seven years, I have been charting medical anniversaries year by year,1234567 restricting them to multiples of 50 years. The 2023 list includes anniversaries for years ending in '23 and '73:

1123

Foundation of the Augustine Priory of St Bartholomew by Rahere, a prebendary of St Paul's Cathedral.

1323

Start of an epidemic of the Black Death, which spread through southern Asia, killing 50 million people by 1353.

1373

John Lelamour compiles the text of the Lelamour herbal.

Birth of Margery Kempe, author of an early autopathography, The Book of Margery Kempe, in which she described a recipe for medicinal dragees.

1473

First printed edition of De rerum natura, written by Lucretius in the first century BC, produced in Brescia, Lombardy.

The first complete Latin edition of The Canon of Medicine, a five-volume medical encyclopedia by Avicenna, Persian physician, astronomer, and philosopher (980–1037), published in Milan.

Death of Sigismondo Polcastro, Paduan physician and natural philosopher (1384–1473).

1523

Birth of Gabriele Falloppio, Italian anatomist and physician (1523–12). In his Observationes anatomicae (1561) he described many anatomical structures, including the Fallopian aqueduct, through which the facial nerve passes after leaving the auditory nerve, the Fallopian hiatus in the anterosuperior part of the petrous bone in the skull, the Fallopian ligament in the groin, and the Fallopian tubes.

1573

Birth of Théodore de Mayerne, Geneva-born Paracelsian physician (1573–1654), fellow of the College of Physicians of London, and contributor to the first edition of the London Pharmacopoeia in 1618.

Death of John Caius, English physician (1510–73), second founder of Gonville and Caius College Cambridge.

The first description of the pons varolii group of nerve fibres in the brain stem in De novis opticis nonnullisque aliis praeter communem opinionem in Humano capite observatis. Ad Hieronymum Mercurialem, Patavii apud Paul et Anton. Meiettos fratres by Costanzo Varolio (1543–75), Italian anatomist and physician to Pope Gregory XIII.

Second edition of De Arte Gymnastica by Girolamo Mercuriale (1530–1606), Italian physician.

1623

Birth of Johann Sigismund Elsholtz, German physician, botanist, and alchemist (1623–88). The author of Anthropometria (1654); in Clysmatica nova (1665) he described his experiments on intravenous injection. The botanical genus Elsholtzia is named after him.

Birth of Georg Balthasar Metzger, German physician and scientist (1623–87), author of various medical works, including Dissertationem medicam inauguralem de medicamentis sternutatoriis (1678).

Birth of William Petty (1623–87), English physician and political economist; he likened governmental interference in a country’s economy to overtreatment of a patient.

Birth of Caspar Schamberger (1623–1706), a German surgeon, who joined the Dutch East India Company in 1643 and established Western-style medicine in Japan in the 1650s.

Death of Francis Anthony, English apothecary, physician, and alchemist (1550–1623), purveyor of aurum potabile and author of Medicinae chymicae et veri potabilis auri assertio (1610).

Publication of Pinax theatrici botanici by Swiss botanist, Gaspard Bauhin (1560–1624), who introduced binomial plant names (genus and species).

Publication of Tratado de las siete enfermedades (Treatise on Seven Maladies), by Aleixeu de Abreu (1568–1630) Abreu, Portuguese physician and tropical pathologist, including descriptions of scurvy, yellow fever, and infections with the Brazilian flea Tunga penetrans, and the Guinea worm or Medina worm, Dracunculus medinensis.

Discovery of the lacteal vessels of the lymphatic system by Gasparus Aselli (1581–1625), Italian physician.

1673

Birth of Richard Mead, English physician, author of A Short Discourse Concerning Pestilential Contagion, and the Method to be Used to Prevent it (1720).

Death of Regnier De Graaf (1641–73), Dutch physician, physiologist, and anatomist, who studied reproduction in female rabbits by injecting dyestuffs into their organs; author of De Virorum Organis Generationi Inservientibus, de Clysteribus et de Usu Siphonis in Anatomia (1668).

Publication of Dissertatio epistolica de formatione pulli in ovo by Marcello Malpighi, Italian physician (1628–94).

Microscopic observations by Antony van Leeuwenhoek (1632–1723), including red blood cells.

Foundation of the Chelsea Physic Garden by the Worshipful Society of Apothecaries.

1723

Birth of Giovanni Antonio Scopoli (1723–88), Italian physician and scientist; he described mercury poisoning in miners in De Hydroargyro Idriensi Tentamina.

Death of Antony van Leeuwenhoek in Delft with what is now called Van Leeuwenhoek's disease (respiratory myoclonus).

Death of Augustus Quirinus Rivinus, German physician and botanist (1652–1723). He introduced improvements in the nomenclature of plants; the notch of Rivinus is in the tympanic part of the temporal bone; his ligament is the flaccid portion of the tympanic membrane, and his ducts are the minor sublingual salivary ducts.

1773

Birth of Aimé Bonpland (1773–1858), French physician and botanist, author of Equatorial Plants (1808–16).

Birth of Thomas Young (1773–1829), English scientist and polymath. He established the wave theory of light, explained the role of the lens in visual accommodation (1793), and was the first to describe astigmatism (1801). He is also the author of An Introduction to Medical Literature, including a System of Practical Nosology (1813) and A Practical and Historical Treatise on Consumptive Diseases (1815); Young’s rule predicts paediatric drug doses—for a child aged A years, multiply the adult dose by A/(A+12).

Publication of A Treatise on the Management of Pregnant and Lying-in Women ... by Charles White (1728–1813), English physician.

Hilaire-Marin Rouelle (1718–79), French chemist, describes sodium and potassium salts and urea in human blood.

1823

Birth of Ludwik Karol Teichmann-Stawiarski, Polish physician and anatomist (1823–95). He introduced injection and corrosion techniques into pathology and used them to study the lymphatic system in health and disease. Haemin crystals, which he discovered, are now known as Teichmann's crystals.

Birth of Alfred Russell Wallace (1823–1913), English naturalist, who independently conceived the theory of evolution through natural selection, contemporaneously with Charles Darwin.

Death of Matthew Baillie, Scottish physician and pathologist (1761-1823), who first identified transposition of the great vessels and situs inversus; author of The Morbid Anatomy of Some of the Most Important Parts of the Human Body (1793).

Death of Edward Jenner, English physician (1749–1823), who introduced vaccination for smallpox using cowpox.

William Prout (1785–1850), English chemist, physician, and theologian, describes gastric acid.

1873

Birth of Hans Berger, German neurologist (1873–1941), inventor of electroencephalography in 1924.

Birth of Alexis Carrel (1873–1944), French surgeon, awarded the Nobel prize in 1912 for pioneering techniques for suturing blood vessels. He also invented the first perfusion pump with Charles Lindbergh.

Birth of Félix d'Herelle, French-Canadian microbiologist (1873–1949), co-discoverer, with Frederick W Twort, of bacteriophages. He tested phage therapy and his work inspired Sinclair Lewis's novel Arrowsmith (1925).

Birth of Otto Loewi, German pharmacologist (1873-1961), who demonstrated the role of acetylcholine as a neurotransmitter and received the Nobel prize in physiology or medicine jointly with Sir Henry Dale in 1936.

Death of Justus von Liebig (1803–73), German chemist, one of the founders of organic chemistry, inventor of the Liebig condenser, and manufacturer of beef extracts. He is the author of Chimie organique appliquée à la physiologie animale et à la pathologie (1842), published in English as Animal Chemistry, or, Organic Chemistry in its Applications to Physiology and Pathology.

Publication of Typhoid Fever: Its Nature, Mode of Spreading, and Prevention, by William Budd (1811–80), English physician.

Publication of Grundzüge der physiologischen Psychologie (Princples of Physiological Psychology) by Wilhelm Wundt (1832–1920), German physiologist.

Gerhard Henrik Armauer Hansen (1841–1912), Norwegian physician, discovers the bacillus, Mycobacterium leprae (Hansen’s bacillus) that causes leprosy (Hansen’s disease).

Joseph Nathan establishes a general trading company in New Zealand, Joseph Nathan and Co., subsequently best known for its dried cow's milk baby food, Glaxo.

1923

Birth of Danny Abse (1923–2014), poet, dramatist, and novelist, author of The Strange Case of Dr Simmonds and Dr Glas (2002), inspired by the Swedish novel Dr Glas (1905) by Hjalmar Soderberg.

Birth of Lloyd Conover, American pharmaceutical chemist (1923–2017), who, working at Pfizer in 1952, produced tetracycline by dechlorinating chlortetracycline.

Birth of Carl Djerassi, American pharmaceutical chemist and novelist (1923–2015); development of hormonal contraceptives.

Birth of Daniel Carleton Gajdusek, American virologist (1923–2008); won the Nobel prize in physiology or medicine, 1976, for research on the transmissibility of kuru.

Birth of Beatrix Hamburg, American psychiatrist (1923–2018) and the first African-American woman to attend Yale Medical School.

Birth of Arthur Jensen, American educational psychologist (1923–2012), who espoused the theory that genetic factors play a major role in the determination of intelligence.

Birth of William P Murphy Jr, American physician and inventor of medical devices, including a sealed flexible bag for blood transfusion, a cardiac pacemaker, a hollow-fibre artificial kidney, and disposable catheters.

Birth of Arnold S Relman, American physician (1923–2014). He was the editor of the New England Journal of Medicine 1977–91.

Death of Wilhelm Röntgen, German physicist (1845–1923), discoverer of x- rays; winner of the Nobel prize 1901.

Gaston Ramon (1886–1963), French biologist, develops tetanus toxoid.

Publication of Introduction to Medical Biometry and Statistics by Raymond Pearl (1879–1940), American biologist.

Foundation of the pharmaceutical company Novo Nordisk in Denmark as Nordisk Insulinlaboratorium, commercialising the production of insulin.

Nobel Prize awarded to Frederick Grant Banting (1891–1941) and John James Richard Macleod (1876–1935) “for the discovery of insulin.”

1973

Roe v Wade 410 US 113; by which the US Supreme Court ruled that the Constitution of the USA conferred the right to have an abortion.

Foundation of the pharmaceutical company Sanofi, as a subsidiary of the French oil company Elf Aquitaine.

During the Norrmalmstorg robbery in Sweden, the hostages bonded with their captors and supported them; this was later called the Stockholm syndrome, a term coined by the Swedish criminologist Nils Bejerot.

Death of Walter Rudolf Hess, Swiss physiologist (1881–1973). He won the Nobel prize in physiology or medicine in 1949 for his discovery of the functional organisation of the interbrain as a coordinator of the activities of the internal organs.

Death of Dickinson W Richards, American physician (1895–1973). He won the Nobel prize in physiology or medicine in 1956, with André Cournand and Werner Forssmann, for discoveries concerning heart catheterisation and pathological changes in the circulatory system.

Death of Selman Waksman, Ukrainian-American biochemist (1888–1973); winner of the Nobel prize in physiology or medicine in 1952 for discovering streptomycin.

Nobel prizes awarded to Karl von Frisch (1886–1982), Konrad Zacharias Lorenz (1903–1989), and Nikolas Tinbergen (1907–1988), for their work in ethology. Von Frisch used conditioning reflex studies to show that bees can distinguish colours and communicate their findings; Lorenz studied animal aggression, imprinting, and the effects of isolation and overcrowding on young primates; Tinbergen studied the homing instincts of digger wasps, the mating rituals of sticklebacks, and colour adaptation in butterflies
